did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections and Archives, George Mason University
did.unittitle: The papers of Harold J. Morowitz 1927 -
did.physdesc: The collection comprises 15 boxes totaling 5 cubic feet ( 7.5 linear feet)

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Harold J. Morowitz papers, Accession #morowitz001, Special Collections and Archives, George Mason University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This is an open collection originally dontated by Mr. Morowitz in 1995

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Dr. Harold J. Morowitz is a biophysicist and Robinson Professor in Biology and Natural Philosophy at George Mason University. He was born in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. on December 4, 1927. Dr. Morowitz earned his B.S. in Physics and Philosophy at in 1947, his M.S. in Physics in 1950 and his Ph.D. in 1951 at Yale University. From 1951 to 1953 he was a physicist at the National Bureau of Standards. He was on the staff of the National Heart Institute from 1953 to 1955, before joining the faculty of Yale Institute in 1955. At Yale University, Dr. Morowitz was as an Assistant Professor from 1955 to 1960, an Associate Professor of biophysics from 1960 to 1967 and a Professor of Molecular biophysics and biochemistry from 1967 to 1988. He was Master of Pierson College from 1981 to 1986. He joined the faculty of George mason University in 1988 as a Robinson Professor and was Director of the Krasnow Institute of Advanced Study from 1993 to 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Morowitz Manuscript Collection includes the following: Energy Flow in Biological Systems: draft copy of the book, including chapter and appendix notes, illustrations, calculations for mathematical operations, and correspondence between the author and his editor; The Beginnings of Cellular Life: draft copy of the work, including the index and notes; The Facts of Life: draft copy of the book, with the "author's copy," and the original artwork for the illustrations; Correspondence with scientists in his and allied fields of study (i.e. Efraim Racker, Albert Einstein, Dr. Peter Mitchell, R.N. Robertson, S.L. Slater) as well as publications of some of these scientists. Archival materials (i.e., working papers, correspondence, etc.) pertaining to his academic career; and some original poetry written by Morowitz.

Includes; "Pumps and Currents: A Biological Perspective by Franklyn M. Harold; Salt Dependence of the Electrical Potential at the Photsynthetic Membrane in Steady-State Light and Its Structural Consequence (12/21/81) by R. Tiemann and H.T. Witt; "Generation of Large and Active membrane Layers from Thylakoid Vesicles" (3/13/81) by H.T. Witt and D. Diore; "A Proton Motive Force Transducer and Its Role in Proton Pumps, Proton Engines, Tobacco Mosaic Virus Assembly and Hemoglobin Allosterism" (1/18/82) by A. Keith Dunker; "The Proton Gradient Across Mycoplasma Membranes" (1981) by Ulrich Schummer, Hans-Gerd Schiefer and Ursala Gerhadt; 'From Black-Box Biogenergetics to Molecular Mechanics:Vectorial Ligand-Conduction Mechanisms in Biochemistry" (1981) by Peter Mitchell; "Relation Between the Initial Kinetics of ATP Synthesis and of Conformational Changes in the Chloroplast ATPase Studied by External Pulses" (9/29/80) by E. Schlodder and H.T. Witt; " The Effective Proton Conductance of the Inner Membrane of Mitochondria from Brown Adipose Tissue' (1/4/77) by David G. Nicholls; "Aqueous Ion Channels" 12/15/80 by D.T.Edmonds; "Proton Pump Coupled to Cytochrome c Oxidace In Mitochondria" (3/17/77) M.K.F. Wikstrom; "The Mechanism of Energy Conservation and Tranduction by Mitochondrial Cytochrome c Oxidase" (4/12/77) by Marten K.F. Wiksrom and Herkko T. Saari; " Proton Semiconductors and Energy Transduction in Biological Systems" (1978) by Harold J. Morowitz; " The Mitchell Hypothesis: A Bibliography" (1975) by Michael G. Prisant
hand written class notes, reproduced for preservation

22 publications by Peter Mitchell:"Oxidation and Photosynthetic Phosphorylation: Vectorial Chemiosmotic Process, 1977; "Vectorial Chemistry and the Molecular Mechanics of Chemiosmotic Coupling: Power Transmition by Proticity, 1976; "A Chemiosmotic Molecular Mechanism for Proton-Transporting Adenosine Triphosphatases", 7/1974; "The Mechanism for Proton Translocation in Reversible Proton-Translocation Adenosine Triphosphatases", 1974; "Proton-Translocation Pyrophosphatase of Rhodospirillum Rumbrum", 6/1972; "Chemiosmotic Coupling in Energy Transduction: A Logical Development of Biochemical Knowledge", 1972; Membranes of Cells and Organelles: Morphology, transport and Metabolism", 1970; Chemiosmotic Coupling and Energy Transduction", 1968; "Bromthymol Blue as a pH Indicator in Microndrial Suspensions", 1968; "Proton-Translocation Phosphorylation in mitochondria, chloroplasts and bacteria: natural fuel cells and solor cells[sic]", 9-10/1967; "Proton Current Flow in Mitochondrial Systems", 6/24/67; "Intramitrachondrial pH: a Statistical Question of Hydrogen Ion Concentration in a Small Element of Space-time", 4/22/67; "Chemiosmotic Hypothesis of Oxidative Phosphorylation", 1/14/67; "Molecule Group and Electron Translocation Through Natural Membranes", 1963; "Group-Translocation: A Consequence of Enzyme-Catalysed Group-transfer", 8/9/58; "Transport of Phosphate Across the Surface of Micrococcus pyrogenes: Nature of the Cell Inorganic Phosphate", 10/1953; " Enzyme Catalysis and Group Translocation", 2/24/58; "The Origin of Life and the Formation and Organising Functions of Natural Membranes", 1957; "Transport of Phosphate across the Omsmotic Barrier of Micrococcus pyrogenes: Specificity and Kinetics", 1954; "The Glycerophospho-protein Complex of Envelope Micrococcus pyrogenes Paths of Phosphate Transfer in Micrococcus pyrogenes: Phosphate Turnover in Nucleic Acids and other Factions", 10/1953; "Assimilation of Amino-acids by Bacteria", 10/1947; "Occurrence of a Phosphoric Ester in Certain Bacteria: Its Relation to Gram Staining and Penicillin Sensitivity, 8/5/50.

Published articles by Peter Mitchell: "The Culture of Imagination", 1980; "Protonmotive Cytochrome System of Mitcohondria", 5/31/80; "David Keilin's Respiratory Chain Concept and its Chemiosmotic Consequences", 1979; "Epilogue From Energetic Abstraction to Biochemical mechanism", 1977; Possible Molecular Mechanisms of the Protonmotive Function of Cytochrome Systems
